_prev_prog_3.Description: The City of Oak Ridge complies with 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management, which is a systematic approach to evaluating the entire process from design to use.  Using the approach, the process design, process technology, operational and maintenance activities and procedures, non-routine activities and procedures, emergency preparedness plans and procedures, training programs and any other elements which impact the process are all considered in the evaluation.  Policies and procedures are written and implemented in accordance with local, State and Federal rules and regulations.  Purchasing of chemicals is limited to the minimum quantity required to accomplish the required task, i.e., chlorine is limited to six, one-ton containers on site at any time.  Buying chemicals in bulk quantities is prohibited.  The City of Oak Ridge ensures workers are informed of chemical hazards in the workplace by complying with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.1200.  The HAZCOM program makes use of MSDSs, labels and training.  Employees receive orientation and specific training for the job they are performing.   Chlorine handling presents the highest risk associated with chemicals at the Water Treatment Plant.  The chlorine feed room and storage area are locked, and only authorized personnel are allowed into this area.  The area is checked a minimum of three times, once per shift, in a 24-hour period during routine inspections.  Chlorine is fed into the water through a "closed" system to prevent personnel contact.  Training is consistent with the requirements in 29 CFR 1910.120(f), Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response.  Public access is blocked when changing containers to minimize risk.  Each activity is monitored until concluded.  When a container is empty, the valve is closed for a few minutes before the feed line is disconnected in order to evacuate the feed line before switching to the second container.  A chlorine detector (Chloralert) monitors the atmosphere in the chlorine feed room where the chlorine containers are in use.

_exec_summary.SummaryText: In May 2000, the City of Oak Ridge assumed ownership and operations of the Y-12 Water Treatment Plant (WTP).  The WTP had been previously owned by the U.S. Department of Energy and operated by East Tennessee Mechanical Contractors (ETMC).  The water system is comprised of three subsystems that include the raw water supply system, the water treatment system and the treated water distribution system.  The system provides water for potability, cooling, process and fire protection needs to approximately 27,000 residents, as well as a host of commercial and government activities at the Y-12 and ORNL Plant sites.  Any interruption in continuous water service will have an immediate harmful impact on plant operations.  The water system is also important to public health and the economic stability of the City of Oak Ridge.  Chlorine, a regulated substance, is used for disinfection purposes in the production of potable water.  The approximate daily usage of chlorine is 170 to350 pounds.  Approximately four (4), one-ton containers are stored at the WTP and two (2), one-ton containers are stored at the River intake/Pump Station.  Two containers are on line at all times.  The WTP uses an average of one container per week and the River Intake/Pump Station uses approximately one container every 12 days; annual chlorine usage is approximately 85,000 pounds.  Chlorine is a yellow-greenish gas with a characteristic penetrating and irritating odor that is highly toxic.  Gas leaks can pose a health hazard to employees and the public and may possibly interrupt water treatment service.  Overexposure to chlorine can cause irritation to the throat and lungs and prolonged exposure can result in death.  Emergency response and process safety management plans have been developed and all personnel that handle chlorine are thoroughly trained prior to operations involving potential chlorine exposure.
